context: Detoxification efforts measured through biotransformation enzymes 2.3.2.1 EROD activity in hepatic tissue Hepatic EROD (or biotransformation) activity was assessed following published protocols (Hersikorn and Smits 2011; Kennedy and Jones 1994) with the following modifications. The homogenate was centrifuged in 5ml ultracentrifuge tubes at 10, 000 g, 2°C, for 10min (Beckmann and Colter Inc., Chino, CA, USA), transferred into a clean tube and centrifuged at 100,000 g, 2°C for 60min. For enzyme activity (CYP 4501A) in the microsomes, 30μl of the substrate 7-ethoxyresorufin (4.7μM), 20μl phosphate buffer (0.05M, pH 8.0), and 60μl samples (~0.5mg/ml microsomal proteins) were incubated in black, 96 well microtiter plates at room temperature for 10min. The reaction was started by adding 30μl β-nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NADPH, 2.4mM) and was run for 15min at 39°C, and stopped with 60μl of a fluorescamine in acetonitrile (0.6mg/ml). The plate was read in a spectrofluorometer (Flexstation II, Molecular Devices LLC, Sunnyvale, CA, USA) with SoftMax Pro 6.0 software at excitation wavelengths of 530–590nm for resorufin and at emission wavelengths of 390–460nm for protein fluorescence. The fluorescence was compared to a standard curve prepared from resorufin salt and fit to a linear curve. The fluorescence of the microsomal protein was compared to a protein standard curve created from heat-inactivated hepatic microsomes and fitted to a 4-parameter logistic curve.

llm_generation.summary: In this context, sulfur dioxide and acetonitrile are both mentioned in relation to biotransformation enzyme activity assessments in hepatic tissue. However, there is no direct interaction or specific relationship discussed between sulfur dioxide and acetonitrile. Acetonitrile is used as a solvent in the fluorescence measurement process, while sulfur dioxide is not directly linked to the enzymatic activity being measured, indicating a lack of significant relevance between the two terms.
